rid=\"apjab886baf5\">5</xref>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf6\">6</xref>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"orcid\">0000-0003-1074-4807</ext-link>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Calzadilla</surname>\n<given-names>Michael S.</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf6\">6</xref>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"orcid\">0000-0002-2238-2105</ext-link>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Floyd</surname>\n<given-names>Benjamin</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf7\">7</xref>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Khullar</surname>\n<given-names>Gourav</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf2\">2</xref>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf3\">3</xref>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"orcid\">0000-0002-3475-7648</ext-link>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>McDonald</surname>\n<given-names>Michael</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf6\">6</xref>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Remolina Gonz&aacute;lez</surname>\n<given-names>Juan D.</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf1\">1</xref>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"orcid\">0000-0002-7868-9827</ext-link>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Schrabback</surname>\n<given-names>Tim</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf8\">8</xref>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Stark</surname>\n<given-names>Antony A.</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf9\">9</xref>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"orcid\">0000-0002-2718-9996</ext-link>\n</contrib>\n<contrib contrib-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>van den Busch</surname>\n<given-names>Jan Luca</given-names>\n</name>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf10\">10</xref>\n<xref ref-type=\"aff\" rid=\"apjab886baf11\">11</xref>\n</contrib>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf1\">\n<label>1</label>Department of Astronomy, University of Michigan, 1085 South University Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, <country>USA</country>; <ext-link id=\"apjab886bem1\" ext-link-type=\"email\">gmahler@umich.edu</ext-link>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf2\">\n<label>2</label>Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, <institution>University of Chicago</institution>, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf3\">\n<label>3</label>Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics, <institution>University of Chicago</institution>, 5640 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf4\">\n<label>4</label>Argonne National Laboratory, High-Energy Physics Division, 9700 S. Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf5\">\n<label>5</label>Department of Physics, <institution>University of Cincinnati</institution>, Cincinnati, OH 45221, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf6\">\n<label>6</label>Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 77 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf7\">\n<label>7</label>Department of Physics and Astronomy, <institution>University of Missouri</institution>, 5110 Rockhill Road, Kansas City, MO 64110, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf8\">\n<label>8</label>Argelander-Institut f&uuml;r Astronomie, Universit&auml;t Bonn, Auf dem H&uuml;gel 71, D-53121 Bonn, <country>Germany</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf9\">\n<label>9</label>Center for Astrophysics &mid; Harvard &amp;&nbsp;Smithsonian, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, <country>USA</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf10\">\n<label>10</label>Argelander-Institut f&uuml;r Astronomie, Universit&auml;t Bonn, Auf dem H&uuml;gel 71, 53121, Bonn, <country>Germany</country>\n</aff>\n<aff id=\"apjab886baf11\">\n<label>11</label>Astronomisches Institut, Ruhr-Universit&auml;t Bochum, Universit&auml;tsstr 150, D-44801 Bochum, <country>Germany</country>\n</aff>\n<author-comment content-type=\"short-author-list\">\n<p>Mahler et al.</p>\n</author-comment>\n</contrib-group>\n<pub-date pub-type=\"ppub\">\n<month>5</month>\n<year>2020</year>\n</pub-date>\n<pub-date pub-type=\"epub\">\n<day>18</day>\n<month>05</month>\n<year>2020</year>\n</pub-date>\n<volume>894</volume>\n<issue>2</issue>\n<elocation-id content-type=\"artnum\">150</elocation-id>\n<history>\n<date date-type=\"received\">\n<day>30</day>\n<month>10</month>\n<year>2019</year>\n</date>\n<date date-type=\"rev-recd\">\n<day>6</day>\n<month>4</month>\n<year>2020</year>\n</date>\n<date date-type=\"accepted\">\n<day>8</day>\n<month>4</month>\n<year>2020</year>\n</date>\n</history>\n<permissions>\n<copyright-statement>&copy; 2020. The American Astronomical Society. All rights reserved.</copyright-statement>\n<copyright-year>2020</copyright-year>\n</permissions>\n<self-uri xlink:href=\"http://stacks.iop.org/APJ/894/150\"/>\n<abstract>\n<title>Abstract</title>\n<p>We present an analysis of the mass distribution inferred from strong lensing by SPT-CL J0356&minus;5337, a cluster of galaxies at redshift <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=1.0359$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.0359</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn1.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> revealed in the follow-up of the SPT-SZ clusters. The cluster has an Einstein radius of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\theta }_{{\\rm{E}}}\\simeq $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&theta;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">E</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&simeq;</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn2.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> 14&Prime; for a source at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;3 and a mass within 500 kpc of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{500\\mathrm{kpc}}=4.0\\pm 0.8\\times {10}^{14}\\,$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>500</mml:mn>\n<mml:mspace width=\"0.25em\"/>\n<mml:mi>kpc</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>4.0</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&PlusMinus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.8</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>14</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mspace width=\"0.25em\"/>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn3.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn4.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> . Our spectroscopic identification of three multiply imaged systems (<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=2.363$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2.363</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn5.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=2.364$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2.364</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn6.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, and <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=3.048$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>3.048</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn7.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>), combined with HSTF606W-band imaging allows us to build a strong lensing model for this cluster with an rms of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $\\leqslant 0\\buildrel{\\prime\\prime}\\over{.} 3$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mo>&le;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&farcs;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn8.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>. Our modeling reveals a two-component mass distribution in the cluster. One mass component is dominated by the brightest cluster Galaxy and the other component, separated by &sim;170 kpc, contains a group of eight red elliptical galaxies confined in a &sim;9&Prime; (&sim;70 kpc) diameter circle. We estimate the mass ratio between the two components to be between 1:1.25 and 1:1.58. In addition, spectroscopic data reveal that these two near-equal mass cores have only a small velocity difference of &sim;300 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup> between the two components. This small radial velocity difference suggests that most of the relative velocity takes place in the plane of the sky, and implies that SPT-CL J0356&minus;5337 is a major merger with a small impact parameter seen face-on. We also assess the relative contributions of Galaxy-scale halos to the overall mass of the core of the cluster and find that within 800 kpc from the brightest cluster Galaxy about 27&percnt; of the total mass can be attributed to visible and dark matter associated with galaxies, whereas only 73&percnt; of the total mass in the core comes from cluster-scale dark matter halos.</p>\n</abstract>\n<kwd-group kwd-group-type=\"author\">\n<title content-type=\"vocab\">unified-astronomy-thesaurus</title>\n<compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"vocab-term-identifier\">http://astrothesaurus.org/uat/584</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"term\">Galaxy clusters</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"uat-code\">584</compound-kwd-part>\n</compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"vocab-term-identifier\">http://astrothesaurus.org/uat/670</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"term\">Gravitational lensing</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"uat-code\">670</compound-kwd-part>\n</compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"vocab-term-identifier\">http://astrothesaurus.org/uat/1643</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"term\">Strong gravitational lensing</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"uat-code\">1643</compound-kwd-part>\n</compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"vocab-term-identifier\">http://astrothesaurus.org/uat/356</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"term\">Dark matter distribution</compound-kwd-part>\n<compound-kwd-part content-type=\"uat-code\">356</compound-kwd-part>\n</compound-kwd>\n</kwd-group>\n<kwd-group kwd-group-type=\"AAS\">\n<kwd>Galaxy clusters</kwd>\n<kwd>Gravitational lensing</kwd>\n<kwd>Strong gravitational lensing</kwd>\n<kwd>Dark matter distribution</kwd>\n</kwd-group>\n<counts>\n<page-count count=\"14\"/>\n</counts>\n<custom-meta-group>\n<custom-meta>\n<meta-name>ccc</meta-name>\n<meta-value>0004-637X/20/150&plus;14&dollar;33.00</meta-value>\n</custom-meta>\n<custom-meta>\n<meta-name>crossmark</meta-name>\n<meta-value>yes</meta-value>\n</custom-meta>\n</custom-meta-group>\n</article-meta>\n</front>\n<body>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs1\">\n<label>1.</label>\n<title>Introduction</title>\n<p>Embedded in the largest gravitationally bound dark matter (DM) halos in the cosmic web, clusters of galaxies are excellent probes of the high-mass end of large scale structure formation. Models of hierarchical growth predict that the majority of the mass of a cluster halo accumulates through multiple minor-merger events, in which small Galaxy-scale or group-scale halos fall into the cluster core. Major mergers (1:3) are rarer; statistically, a typical cluster-scale halo of <italic>M</italic><sub>200</sub>&nbsp;&sim;&nbsp;10<sup>14</sup><inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn9.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0 will have undergone one major-merger event throughout its evolution (Fakhouri &amp; Ma <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib19\">2008</xref>). <italic>M</italic><sub><italic>&delta;</italic></sub> goes the mass in the radius <italic>R</italic><sub><italic>&delta;</italic></sub> that would be reach <italic>&delta;</italic> times the critical density of the universe at that redshifts.</p>\n<p>Major mergers are also uniquely useful for studying the nature of DM. For example, the separation between DM and gas in the Bullet Cluster (1E 0657&minus;558) provides empirical evidence that favors cold DM over theories of modified gravity (Clowe et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib12\">2006</xref>). Analyses of mergers can also constrain the DM self-interaction cross-section (e.g., Markevitch et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib32\">2004</xref>; Harvey et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib23\">2015</xref>) and the large-scale matter&ndash;antimatter ratio (Steigman <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib51\">2008</xref>).</p>\n<p>Structure growth and mergers are studied in simulations and observed up to <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&sim;&nbsp;2. McDonald et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib36\">2017</xref>) consider the density profiles of clusters out to redshift &sim;1.7 that have been rescaled to their <italic>R</italic><sub>500</sub> radius, taking into account the critical density at each epoch, and find that outside the cluster cores the profiles are remarkably similar. Cluster cores deviate from this self-similarity; the complexity of cluster cores can be well probed with a multiwavelength/multiscale approach, in particular, by including strong lensing analysis. Indeed, the angular extent of strong lensing features in cluster fields, from a few to a hundred arcseconds, corresponds to the scale of the cluster core&mdash;a few to hundreds of kiloparsecs in projection.</p>\n<p>Since the prototypical Bullet Cluster (Markevitch et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib33\">2002</xref>) was first identified, a small number of other clusters with structure indicative of major mergers have been observed, and showed spatial dissociation of gas, DM, and galaxies. Most of these systems are at low redshifts. Notable higher redshift systems are &ldquo;El Gordo&rdquo; (ACT-CL J0102-4915) at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.870 (Marriage et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib34\">2011</xref>; Menanteau et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib38\">2012</xref>; Zitrin et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib58\">2015</xref>; Cerny et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib10\">2018</xref>), and the structure of CLJ0152-1347 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.830 (Massardi et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib35\">2010</xref>), a complex system with two main subclusters separated by 722 kpc, complicated by at least one further merging subgroup.</p>\n<p>Only a subset of mergers enable investigation of the full range of phenomena seen in bullet-like mergers, targeting the nature of DM (Dawson et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib16\">2012</xref>): such mergers are those that (1) occur between two subclusters of comparable mass, (2) have a small impact parameter, (3) are observed during the short period when the cluster gas is significantly offset from the galaxies and DM, and (4) occur mostly transverse to the line of sight such that the apparent angular separation of the cluster gas from the galaxies and DM is maximized.</p>\n<p>In this paper we confirm the identification of SPT-CL J0356&minus;5337 (hereafter SPT-0356) as a strong lensing cluster, report on spectroscopic measurements of redshifts of three lensed galaxies behind the cluster, and present the first strong lensing model of the cluster core. We argue that the observed properties of the cluster, combined with the strong lensing mass model, promotes SPT-0356 as the highest-redshift major-merger cluster candidate.</p>\n<p>At <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=1.0359$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.0359</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn10.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, SPT-0356 is one of the most distant clusters known with spectroscopically confirmed strong lensing evidence at the cluster scale from multiple systems. The lensing geometry offers a unique opportunity to weigh the mass within the core of the cluster. Strong lensing clusters at redshifts <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&ge;&nbsp;1, include SPT-CLJ2011&minus;5228 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.06 (Collett et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib13\">2017</xref>), which has only one multiply imaged system; SPT-CLJ0546&minus;5345 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.066 (Brodwin et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib9\">2010</xref>), which shows evidence of strong lensing features (Staniszewski et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib50\">2009</xref>); and SPT-CLJ0205&minus;5829 (Stalder et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib48\">2013</xref>; Bleem et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib5\">2015</xref>) at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.322 which has one arc with no published redshift. Wong et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib56\">2014</xref>) also report on a lensed galaxy with spectroscopic redshifts behind a cluster at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.62. However, the lensing signal comes essentially from the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) embedded in the cluster, thus this lens offers little or no leverage on the cluster-scale mass distribution. The highest redshift cluster with strong lensing evidence currently published is IDCSJ1426 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.75 (Gonzalez et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib22\">2012</xref>), but there is no public spectroscopic redshift measurement for the only giant arc reported.</p>\n<p>This paper is organized as follows: in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs2\">2</xref>, we report on the identification and previous analyses of SPT-0356. In Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs3\">3</xref>, we describe the data that are used in this paper. In Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs4\">4</xref>, we define the cluster-member selection, which is an important input to the strong lens modeling described and analyzed in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5\">5</xref>. In Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs6\">6</xref>, we discuss our results and we summarize this work in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs7\">7</xref>.</p>\n<p>Throughout this paper, we adopt a standard &Lambda;-CDM cosmology with &OHgr;<sub><italic>m</italic></sub>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.3, &OHgr;<sub>&Lambda;</sub>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.7, and <italic>h</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.7. All magnitudes are given in the AB system (Oke <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib41\">1974</xref>).</p>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs2\">\n<label>2.</label>\n<title>SPT-CL J0356&minus;5337</title>\n<p>Bleem et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib5\">2015</xref>) first identified and published SPT-0356&nbsp;as a strong-lensing cluster, as part of a catalog of Galaxy clusters selected from South Pole Telescope (SPT) data based on the Sunyaev&ndash;Zel&rsquo;dovich effect (SZ,Sunyaev &amp; Zeldovich <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib52\">1970</xref>). Bocquet et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib6\">2019</xref>) published an updated mass for this system of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{500c}={3.59}_{-0.66}^{+0.59}\\times {10}^{14}{h}_{70}^{-1}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>500</mml:mn>\n<mml:mi>c</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>3.59</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.66</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.59</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>14</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>h</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>70</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn11.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn12.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> assuming the same fixed &Lambda;-CDM cosmology we adopt in this work.</p>\n<p>Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>) used the Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph (GMOS) on the Gemini South Observatory in Chile to measure spectroscopic redshifts of 36 galaxies in this field, eight of which were spectroscopically identified as cluster members, including the BCG (see Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref>). From these eight cluster members with GMOS spectra, Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>) determine a median cluster redshift of <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.0345&nbsp;&PlusMinus;&nbsp;0.0112, with a velocity dispersion of <italic>&sgr;</italic><sub><italic>v</italic></sub>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1691&nbsp;&PlusMinus;&nbsp;588 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>. In a reanalysis of these data, Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib3\">2017</xref>) report a revised median redshift of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=1.0359\\pm 0.0042$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.0359</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&PlusMinus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.0042</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn13.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> and <italic>&sgr;</italic><sub><italic>v</italic></sub>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1647&nbsp;&PlusMinus; 514 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>, based on four of the eight galaxies whose spectral features indicate that they are either passive or post-starburst, so that their velocities are likely less sensitive to recent accretion. In this paper, we adopt as the cluster redshift the measurement of Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib3\">2017</xref>), <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp; 1.0359, used hereafter without uncertainties. We note that these measurements are consistent with each other, and the slight difference between these redshifts has no significant effect on our analysis or results. Initial follow-up imaging of the SPT-SZ clusters led to the identification of strong lensing evidence in 23 clusters above <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z\\gt 0.7$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&gt;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.7</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn14.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> (Bleem et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib5\">2015</xref>). Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf2\">2</xref> plots the mass and redshift of SPT-0356 compared to the entire Bleem et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib5\">2015</xref>) sample, with the strong lenses highlighted; SPT-0356 is among the highest-redshift strong lenses in this sample. The lensing evidence, shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref>, include three sets of multiple images of background sources. Each system has three multiple images, all appearing west of the BCG. The high resolution of the HST/ACS single-band imaging (in F606W, shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref> ) revealed substructure in each of the images, strongly suggesting that the three images of each system are indeed multiple images of the same source. This identification was also supported by the observed symmetry, which is consistent with expectations from the lensing geometry, and prompted follow-up spectroscopy. Here, we report nine lensed images of three distinct sources in the field of SPT-0356</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf1\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 1.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc1\">\n<p>HST/ACS imaging with the F606W filter, from GO-13412. The red contours correspond to the critical curve at redshift <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;3.048 and match the lens model with 1 DM component free to move, model B. (See Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5\">5</xref> for more details.) The green squares label the GMOS spectroscopic data within the FoV from Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>). All the other colored solid circles represent the FIRE data and match the colored legend in the figure. The dashed circles are the identified counter images of lensed systems. The white dashed box shows the position of the inset on the right. This inset shows a zoomed view of the three multiply imaged systems, where the arrow and numbers indicate the lensing configurations and constraints used in the model following a color coding to match the lensed system.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf1_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf1.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf1_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf1_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf1_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf1_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf2\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 2.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc2\">\n<p>Comparison of SPT-0356 to other clusters in the SPT-SZ 2500 deg<sup>2</sup> from Bleem et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib5\">2015</xref>). Clusters identified as strong lenses are labeled with red circles, and several well-studied &ldquo;bullet&rdquo; clusters (i.e., dissociative merger) are highlighted. SPT-0356 is among the highest redshift strong lensing clusters in this sample.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf2_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf2.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf2_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf2_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf2_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf2_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs3\">\n<label>3.</label>\n<title>Data</title>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs3-1\">\n<label>3.1.</label>\n<title>Imaging</title>\n<p>Optical imaging follow-up observations of SPT-0356 were conducted with several telescopes and instruments:</p>\n<p><italic>Magellan</italic>&mdash;The cluster was first imaged with the Inamori-Magellan Areal Camera &amp; Spectrograph (IMACS) on Magellan Baade 6.5 m telescope as part of the SPT cluster confirmation efforts on 2012 December 16. Each IMACS observation covers a field of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $13^{\\prime} \\times 27^{\\prime} $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mn>13</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo accent=\"false\">&prime;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>27</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo accent=\"false\">&prime;</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn15.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, observed for 400&nbsp;s with each of the <italic>g</italic>, <italic>r</italic>, and <italic>z</italic> filters.</p>\n<p>The cluster was observed with the Magellan Clay 6.5 m telescope at Las Campanas Observatory, using the Parallel Imager for Southern Cosmology Observations (PISCO) instrument (Stalder et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib49\">2014</xref>) as part of a uniform optical follow-up program on 2016 December 31. Each PISCO observation covers a <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $9\\buildrel{\\,\\prime}\\over{.} 5\\times 6^{\\prime} $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mn>9</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&farcm;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>5</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>6</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo accent=\"false\">&prime;</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn16.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> area on the sky centered on the cluster, observed in parallel in four different bands (<italic>g</italic>, <italic>r</italic>, <italic>i</italic>, and <italic>z</italic>) for an exposure time of 258 seconds.</p>\n<p><italic>Hubble Space Telescope</italic>&mdash;HST imaging of SPT-0356 was obtained with the Advanced Camera for Survey (ACS) camera as part of the SPT-SZ ACS Snapshot Survey (Cycle 21, GO-13412; PI: Schrabback). A single image was obtained in F606W on 2014 June 25, with total exposure time of 2320&nbsp;s. The ACS field of view covers a <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $3\\buildrel{\\,\\prime}\\over{.} 3\\times 3\\buildrel{\\,\\prime}\\over{.} 3$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&farcm;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&farcm;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>3</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn17.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> area, centered on the SZ peak.</p>\n<p><italic>Gemini</italic>&mdash;Deep <italic>i</italic>-band and <italic>g</italic>-band images were obtained with the Gemini South Observatory 8.1 m telescopes as part of the weak lensing follow-up of SPT-SZ clusters (PI: Benson) from the SPT-SZ ACS Snapshot Survey using the GMOS camera. We used a 2&nbsp;&times;&nbsp;2 binned stacked image reaching 5200&nbsp;s exposure time and 1&farcs;17 seeing on the central chip covering the HST/ACS field of view. The data were obtained on 2014 December 30.</p>\n<p>Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf3\">3</xref> shows the cluster core field of view, rendered from the GMOS and HST imaging. These represent the deepest and highest resolution data in hand. We supplement these data with the shallower, lower resolution, <italic>z</italic>-band imaging from IMACS and PISCO, in order to achieve broad wavelength coverage, where color information is needed for assessing candidate strong lensing features.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf3\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 3.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc3\">\n<p>Color composite image of the field, rendered from Gemini <italic>i</italic>-band (red), HST/ACS F606W (green) and Gemini <italic>g</italic>-band (blue). The yellow ellipses mark selected cluster member galaxies that are in the field of view (see Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs4\">4</xref>).</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf3_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf3.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf3_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf3_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf3_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf3_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs3-2\">\n<label>3.2.</label>\n<title>Spectroscopy of Lensed Sources</title>\n<p><italic>Gemini/GMOS</italic>&mdash;The Gemini/GMOS-South spectroscopic survey of SPT-SZ clusters (Bayliss et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>) targeted SPT-0356, resulting in spectroscopic redshifts for the cluster and eight cluster member galaxies (Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs2\">2</xref>). Slits were placed on at least one image of each of the lensed sources. These spectra resulted in a redshift limit of 1.78&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;<italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;3.9 based on weak continuum and lack of spectroscopic features in the spectra within the wavelength coverage of the data, &Delta;<italic>&lambda;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;5920&ndash;10350 &angst;. We note that Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>) provide a &ldquo;best guess&rdquo; redshift for image 2.2 (A.1 in their notation) <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;2.1955, based on very weak spectroscopic features in emission (their Figure 9, panel (c)), but caution that these may be misidentified. The FIRE data, described below, rule out this solution.</p>\n<p><italic>Magellan/LDSS3</italic>&mdash;We obtained multislit spectroscopy of the lensed images using the Magellan Clay telescope with the Low Dispersion Survey Spectrograph (LDSS3-C) on 2018 January 9 (PI: Sharon). The observations were conducted under good conditions with subarcsecond seeing, and slits were placed on eight out of the nine lensed images. However, none of the observations resulted in a redshift measurement for the multiply imaged systems, due to the wavelength coverage of the instrument and the absence of strong enough Ly<italic>&agr;</italic> emission.</p>\n<p><italic>Magellan/FIRE</italic>&mdash;Near-IR spectroscopy yielded robust spectroscopic redshifts for several objects of interest in the field. We observed multiple sources in the core of SPT-0356 with the Folded-port Infrared Echellette (FIRE; Simcoe et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib46\">2013</xref>) spectrograph at the Magellan-I Baade telescope. Observations took place on 2018 January 28&ndash;29 (PI: Gladders); the median seeing during the time of observation was 1&farcs;0, and the airmass ranged between 1.1 and 2.0.</p>\n<p>In total, we observed five different positions in the field using the 1&farcs;0&nbsp;&times;&nbsp;6&farcs;0 slit, with FIRE in high resolution echelette mode. The slit was set at position angles chosen to allow a clean nod of 2&farcs;0 along the slit between neighboring science exposures, and two of the slit positions yielded traces from two sources of interest. With the 1&farcs;0 wide slit FIRE delivers spectra with a resolution of <italic>R</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;3600 (<italic>&sgr;</italic><sub><italic>v</italic></sub>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;83 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>) and covers a wavelength range of 0.82&ndash;2.5 <italic>&mgr;</italic>m in a single-object cross-dispersed setup (Simcoe et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib45\">2008</xref>). We reduced the data using the FIRE reduction pipeline (FIREHOSE)<xref ref-type=\"fn\" rid=\"apjab886bfn1\"><sup>12</sup></xref>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bfn1\">\n<label><sup>12</sup></label>\n<p>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"uri\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"http://web.mit.edu/&#x0007E;rsimcoe/www/FIRE/ob_data.htm\">http://web.mit.edu/&#x0007E;rsimcoe/www/FIRE/ob_data.htm</ext-link>\n</p>\n</fn>; our observations resulted in clear astrophysical emission lines in sky-subtracted 2D spectra for seven distinct sources observed across the five different slit positions, and no continuum emission detection. For emission line sources FIREHOSE allows manual identification of source traces using individual emission lines. The user-supplied line positions and trace location are combined with a trace model to extract object spectra by jointly fitting the source trace along with the two-dimensional sky spectrum using the source-free regions along the slit. We also performed observations of A0V telluric standard stars during the night of our science observations and at similar airmass. The A0V spectra were used to calibrate the extracted science spectra (Vacca et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib54\">2003</xref>) using the xtellcor procedure as a part of the spextool pipeline (Cushing et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib14\">2004</xref>), which is called as a part of the FIREHOSE reduction process.</p>\n<p>We measured cosmological redshifts for each source with an extracted FIRE spectrum by identifying families of nebular emission lines&mdash;H<italic>&agr;</italic>, H<italic>&beta;</italic>, H<italic>&gamma;</italic>, [N <sc>ii</sc>] at <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $\\lambda \\lambda $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>&lambda;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mi>&lambda;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn18.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> 6855, [O <sc>iii</sc>] at <italic>&lambda;&lambda;</italic>4960,5008, and [O <sc>ii</sc>] at <italic>&lambda;&lambda;</italic>3727,3729&mdash;and fitting a Gaussian profile to each emission line. We estimated the mean redshift for each spectrum as the average of the individual line redshifts, and the uncertainty as the quadrature sum of the uncertainties in the individual line centroids from each Gaussian profile, the uncertainty in the wavelength solution (always highly subdominant), and the scatter in the measured redshifts of the individual emission lines. Individual source redshifts are labeled in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref> with solid circles, given in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt1\">1</xref> and the extracted emission line spectra of those sources are shown in Figures <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf8\">A1</xref>, <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf9\">B1</xref>&ndash;<xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf11\">B3</xref>.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt1\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Table 1</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886btc1\">\n<p>Emission Lines Detected in the FIRE Spectra for the Lensed Systems</p>\n</caption>\n<table>\n<colgroup>\n<col align=\"left\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n</colgroup>\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">System</th>\n<th align=\"center\"><italic>z</italic></th>\n<th align=\"center\">Restframe Emission Lines</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">System 1</td>\n<td align=\"center\">2.363</td>\n<td align=\"center\">[O <sc>iii</sc>]<italic>&lambda;&lambda;</italic>4960,5008</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan=\"3\">\n<hr/>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">System 2</td>\n<td align=\"center\">2.364</td>\n<td align=\"center\">[O <sc>ii</sc>]<italic>&lambda;&lambda;</italic>3727,3729</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\"/>\n<td align=\"center\"/>\n<td align=\"center\">[O <sc>iii</sc>]<italic>&lambda;&lambda;</italic>4960,5008</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\"/>\n<td align=\"center\"/>\n<td align=\"center\">H<italic>&agr;</italic>6563</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan=\"3\">\n<hr/>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">System 3</td>\n<td align=\"center\">3.048</td>\n<td align=\"center\">[O <sc>iii</sc>]<italic>&lambda;&lambda;</italic>4960,5008</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\"/>\n<td align=\"center\"/>\n<td align=\"center\">H<italic>&gamma;</italic>4340</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<graphic xlink:href=\"apjab886bt1_tb.gif\"/>\n<graphic xlink:href=\"apjab886bt1_lr.gif\">\n<caption>\n<p>Typeset image</p>\n</caption>\n</graphic>\n</table-wrap>\n</sec>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs4\">\n<label>4.</label>\n<title>Selection of Cluster Members</title>\n<p>We identified cluster-member galaxies by color, using the red sequence technique (Gladders &amp; Yee <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib21\">2000</xref>) from a GMOS <italic>i</italic>-band and HST/ACS F606W color&ndash;magnitude diagram (Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf4\">4</xref>). To measure galaxy colors, we first aligned and resampled the GMOS <italic>i</italic>-band image to match the ACS pixel frame, and used Source Extractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib4\">1996</xref>) in dual-image mode with the GMOS-<italic>i</italic>-band as the detection image. Magnitudes were measured as MAG_AUTO<xref ref-type=\"fn\" rid=\"apjab886bfn2\"><sup>13</sup></xref>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bfn2\">\n<label><sup>13</sup></label>\n<p>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"uri\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"https://www.astromatic.net/pubsvn/software/sextractor/trunk/doc/sextractor.pdf\">https://www.astromatic.net/pubsvn/software/sextractor/trunk/doc/sextractor.pdf</ext-link>\n</p>\n</fn> within the <italic>i</italic>-band detection aperture in both images.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf4\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 4.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc4\">\n<p>Color&ndash;magnitude diagram of galaxies within the ACS field of view. The galaxies that are selected as the red sequence are marked with red star symbols; filled symbols are galaxies within 75&farcs;6 from the BCG. Galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts at the cluster redshift are labeled in yellow.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf4_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf4.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf4_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf4_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf4_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf4_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<p>Stars and other artifacts were rejected from the catalog based on their location in a MU_MAX versus MAG_AUTO diagram in the HST photometry. The BCG and the other spectroscopically confirmed galaxies (Bayliss et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>) were used to identify the red sequence locus in color&ndash;magnitude space. We include in the cluster-member catalog galaxies brighter than <italic>i</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;25 mag that lie within 75&farcs;6 in projection from the BCG, where both the ACS and GMOS images have complete coverage. Being far from the center, the galaxies in the outskirts do not have a significant impact on the mass at the cluster core or the lensing configuration. Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf4\">4</xref> shows the selection made for cluster member galaxies.</p>\n<p>We attempted constructing cluster-member catalogs with and without convolving the HST image with the much larger GMOS point-spread function (psf). We find that while the red sequence becomes more diffuse due to contamination from bright nearby objects, the overall selection of cluster members is not significantly affected. After examining the discrepancies, we conservatively choose to use the photometry based on the natural resolution of the HST image to reduce contamination. We note that only two faint galaxies (with <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $i\\gt 24$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>i</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&gt;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>24</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn19.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>) near the cluster core are marginally near the color&ndash;magnitude cut, and would be selected by the psf-matched procedure. High-resolution near-IR data would be required to unambiguously determine cluster membership. Our final cluster member catalog contains 45 galaxies within 75&farcs;6 of the BCG. The selected cluster member galaxies are marked with yellow ellipses in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf3\">3</xref>.</p>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5\">\n<label>5.</label>\n<title>Lensing Analysis and Mass Models</title>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5-1\">\n<label>5.1.</label>\n<title>Lens Modeling Methodology</title>\n<p>We compute a mass model of the core of SPT-0356 from the strong lensing evidence, using the publicly available lensing algorithm <monospace>Lenstool</monospace> (Jullo et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib26\">2007</xref>). We refer the reader to Kneib et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib27\">1996</xref>), Smith et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib47\">2005</xref>), Verdugo et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib55\">2011</xref>), and Richard et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib43\">2011</xref>) for more details on the strong lens modeling approach used in this work. This section provides a short summary. We model the cluster mass distribution as a series of dual pseudo-isothermal ellipsoid (dPIE, El&iacute;asd&oacute;ttir et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib18\">2007</xref>) parametric mass halos, with seven free parameters: the position &Delta;<italic>&agr;</italic>, &Delta;<italic>&delta;</italic>; ellipticity <italic>&epsi;</italic>; position angle <italic>&theta;</italic>; normalization <italic>&sgr;</italic><sub>0</sub>; truncation radius <italic>r</italic><sub>cut</sub>; and core radius <italic>r</italic><sub>core</sub>. We use as constraints the positions of prominent emission clumps in each lensed image, and the spectroscopic redshifts of the lensed sources (see Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-2\">5.2</xref>). The <monospace>Lenstool</monospace> algorithm uses a Monte Carlo Markov Chain (MCMC) formalism to explore the parameter space. It identifies the best fit as the set of parameters that minimize the scatter between the observed and predicted image-plane positions of the lensed features.</p>\n<p>The lens plane is modeled as a combination of cluster-scale and galaxy-scale dPIE halos. For the cluster-scale DM halos, we fix the truncation radius (<italic>r</italic><sub>cut</sub>) at 1500 kpc, since it is too far beyond the strong lensing regime to be constrained by the strong lensing evidence. The other parameters are generally allowed to be solved for by the lens model, unless otherwise indicated.</p>\n<p>Galaxy-scale halos represent the contribution to the lensing potential from cluster member galaxies (Section <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf4\">4</xref>). Their positional parameters (&Delta;<italic>&agr;</italic>, &Delta;<italic>&delta;</italic>; <italic>&epsi;</italic>; <italic>&theta;</italic>) are fixed to their observed values as measured with Source Extractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib4\">1996</xref>). To keep the number of model parameters manageable, the slope parameters of the Galaxy-scale potentials are scaled to their observed <italic>i</italic>-band luminosity with respect to <italic>L</italic><sup>&ast;</sup>, using a parameterized mass&ndash;luminosity scaling relation (see Limousin et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib29\">2007</xref> and discussion therein on the validity of such parameterization) leaving only <italic>r</italic><sub>cut</sub> and the central velocity dispersion (<italic>&sgr;</italic><sub>0</sub>) free to vary. The BCG is modeled separately, since we do not expect it to necessarily follow the same scaling relation (Newman et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib39\">2013a</xref>, <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib40\">2013b</xref>).</p>\n<p>A bright star-forming &ldquo;jellyfish&rdquo; Galaxy (Ebeling et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib17\">2014</xref>), at the cluster redshift, appears 7&farcs;0 east of the BCG and is not included in the cluster-member catalog, as its brightness significantly deviates from the mass&ndash;luminosity relation of the passive cluster member galaxies. This galaxy is far enough from the multiply imaged systems to not significantly affect the lensing configuration, and for the purpose of the lensing analysis it mainly contributes a small increase in the total mass, which is expected to be degenerate with the cluster scale DM clump. We discuss this galaxy in Appendix <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bapp1\">A</xref>.</p>\n<p>As explained below in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-3\">5.3</xref>, we consider several lens models, each with a different number of cluster-scale DM halos and modeling assumptions. In all cases, we require that the number of free parameters is smaller than or equal to the number of constraints. We note, however, that given the small number of lensed sources observed with the existing data, the model may be under-constrained even if this criterion is formally satisfied.</p>\n<p>The lensing constraints (Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-2\">5.2</xref>) come from the identified image-plane locations of multiple images of the lensed sources, and individual emission knots within each Galaxy. The multiple constraints within each Galaxy assist in constraining the lensing parity, and provide leverage over the relative magnification between the images, without explicitly using the flux ratios as constraints. The latter can sometimes be affected by variability (e.g., Fohlmeister et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib20\">2008</xref>; Dahle et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib15\">2015</xref>).</p>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5-2\">\n<label>5.2.</label>\n<title>Lensing Constraints</title>\n<p>Bayliss et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>) identified three arc candidates in the field of SPT-0356, and constrained their redshift to the range 1.78&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;<italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;3.9 based on lack of emission lines in their Gemini-GMOS spectroscopy. Here, we refine the identification and report nine lensed images of three distinct sources in the field of SPT-0356. Each source has three lensed images. As described in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs3-2\">3.2</xref>, we obtained spectroscopic redshifts of at least one image in each system. Constraining the model with spectroscopic redshifts is crucial for a precise and accurate lens model (Johnson &amp; Sharon <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib25\">2016</xref>).</p>\n<p>While ground-based data can reveal strong-lensing evidence, accurate modeling of the mass distribution requires HST resolution to precisely select multiply imaged features used as constraints. The positions of the images are marked in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref>, color-coded by system; the inset shows a zoomed-in view of the three systems. The HST data resolve the galaxies and reveal their internal morphology; system 2 and system 3 show clear distinct emission knots that we use as constraints in order to better probe the mass profile of the Galaxy cluster. Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt2\">2</xref> summarizes the positions and the spectroscopic redshifts of these systems. The unique morphology of system&nbsp;1 and system&nbsp;2, and the identical morphology observed in their multiple images, result in a robust identification even without spectroscopic confirmation of all three images of each system as was obtained for system&nbsp;3.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt2\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Table 2</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886btc2\">\n<p>Secure Multiply image</p>\n</caption>\n</graphic>\n<table-wrap-foot>\n<p><bold>Note.</bold> System refers to the name of the group of images coming from the same source Galaxy. ID refers to the name of the image. R.A. and Decl. are the R.A. and decl. position (J2000) of the image. Spec-<italic>z</italic> is the measured spectroscopic redshifts. dist, often called individual rms, refers to the distance in the image plane between the image an the projected geometrical center of the source. For each system the source position is determined by the geometric mean of source plane positions of individual images.</p>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n<p>In addition to the secure, spectroscopically confirmed multiply imaged galaxies, we identify three candidate multiply imaged systems. Since the strong lensing model is used to help identify these candidates, we do not use those systems as constraints. Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt3\">3</xref> indicates the position of the identified multiple image candidate systems.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt3\" R.A. and Decl. are the R.A. and decl. position (J2000) of the image.</p>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5-3\">\n<label>5.3.</label>\n<title>DM Halos</title>\n<p>We compute four models with one or two DM halos and varying free parameters, to investigate the spatial distribution of DM in the cluster core with respect to the stellar component. These models are summarized in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>, and described below.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt4\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Table 4</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886btc4\">\n<p>Candidate Lens Models and Best-fit Parameters</p>\n</caption>\n<table>\n<colgroup>\n<col align=\"left\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n</colgroup>\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">Model Name</th>\n<th align=\"center\">Component</th>\n<th align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">&Delta;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mi>&agr;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${0.82}_{-0.02}^{+0.00}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- xlink:href=\"apjab886bt4_tb.gif\"/>\n<graphic xlink:href=\"apjab886bt4_lr.gif\">\n<caption>\n<p>Typeset image</p>\n</caption>\n</graphic>\n<table-wrap-foot>\n<p><bold>Notes.</bold> Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters &nbsp; We report statistical quantities such as the Bayesian Information criterion (BIC), the corrected Akaike information criterion (AICc), the likelihood log(<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${ \\mathcal L }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn77.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>) the number of free parameter <italic>k</italic>, and the sample size <italic>n</italic>.</p>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bt4fna\">\n<label><sup>a</sup></label>\n<p>\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">&Delta;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mi>&agr;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn78.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> and <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\delta $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">&Delta;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mi>&delta;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn79.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (<italic>&agr;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;59.0896383, <italic>&delta;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;&minus;53.6310962).</p>\n</fn>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bt4fnb\">\n<label><sup>b</sup></label>\n<p>Ellipticity (<italic>&epsiv;</italic>) is defined to be <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $({a}^{2}-{b}^{2})/({a}^{2}+{b}^{2})$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>a</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>b</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"true\">&sol;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>a</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>b</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn80.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, where <italic>a</italic> and <italic>b</italic> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p>\n</fn>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bt4fnc\">\n<label><sup>c</sup></label>\n<p>\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\sigma }_{0}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&sgr;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn81.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${r}_{\\mathrm{cut}}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>r</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>cut</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn82.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, and <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${r}_{\\mathrm{core}}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>r</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>core</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn83.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> are, respectively, the central velocity dispersion, the cut radius, and the core radius as defined for the dPIE potential used in our modelization. For <italic>L</italic><sup>&ast;</sup> galaxy this value represents the parameter of the galaxy that we optimized for our mass-to-light ratio. We refer the reader to Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-1\">5.1</xref> for a summary, and Limousin et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib29\">2007</xref>) and El&iacute;asd&oacute;ttir et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib18\">2007</xref>) for a more detailed description of the potential. The likelihood is computed as log(<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${ \\mathcal L }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn84.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> &equals; <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $-0.5{\\chi }^{2}.$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.5</mml:mn>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&chi;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mi>.</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn85.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> and the uncertainty used in the <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\chi }^{2}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&chi;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn86.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> computation is computed as <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $\\sigma =\\mathrm{rms}* \\sqrt{(N-k-1)/N}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>&sgr;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>rms</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&ast;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msqrt>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>N</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>k</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"true\">&sol;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>N</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msqrt>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn87.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> where the correcting factor unbiased the rms distribution. We used a unique value of <italic>&sgr;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.19 computed using model B. Due to the homogeneity of our individual positional uncertainties (Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt2\">2</xref>, a small variation of the <italic>&sgr;</italic> will not affect our results).</p>\n</fn>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n<p>The spatial distribution of cluster-member galaxies appears to be separate in two components, with a concentration of cluster-member galaxies grouped &sim;150 kpc west of the BCG. The formation of the arcs between the BCG and this concentration of galaxies indicates that the underlying DM mass distribution of the cluster may also show a two-component structure. Similar lensing configurations are seen in several lower-redshift clusters, whose lens models are dominated by two cluster-scale DM halos (e.g., Sharon et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib44\">2020</xref>). To test the hypothesis that this cluster is also dominated by two halos, we compute two sets of lens models: The first set of models, labeled A and B, have one cluster-scale DM halo (DM1 in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>). A second set of models, labeled C and D, have two cluster-scale DM halos (DM1 and DM2 in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>). In models A and C, the center of DM1 is not fixed, adding two free parameters to these models. Contribution of cluster-member galaxies is included in all models in the same way, as explained in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-1\">5.1</xref>. DM1 is assumed to be located at or near the position of the BCG, for two reasons. First, the BCG presents a regular luminosity profile which suggests that it is not disturbed and therefore this Galaxy would be at the cluster center. Second, we lack the ability to properly constrain the Eastern extent of the cluster since we do not identify secure lensing constraints in this region at the depth of the existing data. The position of DM2 is free with a loose prior that positions it around the group of galaxies on the western part of the cluster. We chose that location as it is more likely that the DM clump is located close to a luminous counterpart (Broadhurst et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib8\">2000</xref>, <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib7\">2005</xref>).</p>\n<p>The second hypothesis we investigate is whether the BCG and its associated DM halo sit at the center of the cluster-scale DM halo. To test this scenario, we fix the position of DM1 to the position of the BCG in models B and D.</p>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5-4\">\n<label>5.4.</label>\n<title>Lens Modeling Results</title>\n<p>Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref> lists the best-fit values of the lens model parameters for each one of the four test models. To evaluate the lens models, we employ two statistical criteria, as described below. One criterion is named rms and represents the average difference between the observed position of a multiple image and the predicted position from the geometrical center of the best-fit model in the image plane given in arcseconds. Thus we seek to reduce the rms as much as possible. The models with one cluster-scale DM clump show an rms of 0&farcs;3 and 0&farcs;1 for the fixed and free DM halo respectively. The models with two cluster-scale DM clumps result in better rms of 0&farcs;06 and 0&farcs;07 for the fixed and free DM halo, respectively.</p>\n<p>The rms criterion suggests that the models with two cluster-scale DM halos are significantly better; however, this criterion does not account for the increased flexibility due to the additional free parameters. To account for that, we further evaluate the models using a second criterion, the Bayesian information criterion (BIC), which was presented in previous works (see Section 5.1 in Mahler et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib30\">2018</xref>; Lagattuta et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib28\">2017</xref>; Acebron et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib1\">2017</xref>). The BIC enables a quantitative comparison between similar models; it is a statistical measurement based on the model likelihood <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${ \\mathcal L }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn88.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, penalized by the number of free parameters <italic>k</italic> and the sample size <italic>n</italic> (i.e., 2&times; the number of multiple images):<disp-formula id=\"apjab886beqn1\">\n<label>1</label>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA \\begin{eqnarray}\\mathrm{BIC}=-2\\times \\mathrm{log}({ \\mathcal L })+k\\times \\mathrm{log}(n).\\end{eqnarray}?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>BIC</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>log</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>k</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>log</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>n</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>.</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886beqn1.gif\"/>\n</disp-formula>We seek to maximize the likelihood (or reduce the first term of Equation (<xref ref-type=\"disp-formula\" rid=\"apjab886beqn1\">1</xref>)). However, arbitrarily increasing the number of free parameters would overfit the data. The second term provides means of balancing the overfitting. It represents a combination of the number of constraints and the number of free parameters and increases the global value of the BIC. We seek the lowest BIC possible. Using the BIC will help us estimate the improvement of the likelihood in comparison with the freedom allowed by the new parameters such as the secondary halo or freeing the position of DM1.</p>\n<p>The number of constraints is identical among all models and is computed as follows:<disp-formula id=\"apjab886beqn2\">\n<label>2</label>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA \\begin{eqnarray}N=({n}_{\\mathrm{im}}\\times 2-{n}_{\\mathrm{src}}\\times 2),\\end{eqnarray}?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>N</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>n</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>im</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>n</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>src</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>,</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886beqn2.gif\"/>\n</disp-formula>where <italic>n</italic><sub>im</sub> refers to the number of images and <italic>n</italic><sub>src</sub> the number of sources. It is recommended to only compare similar models because otherwise the likelihood will not be a similar description of the model performance.</p>\n<p>We discuss here the performance of the four models. To avoid possible confusion we will refer to the model letter as listed in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>.</p>\n<p>Model A, with one cluster halo at a fixed position, has an rms of 0&farcs;3 and a BIC of 20. Freeing the halo center as was done in model B reduces the rms to 0&farcs;1 and the BIC to &minus;16. This is a considerable improvement, indicating that according to both the rms and the BIC criteria model B, with a free halo, is a better fit to the lensing constraints than model A.</p>\n<p>We compare models A and C&mdash;the two models with fixed &ldquo;main&rdquo; DM halo, but with and without a secondary halo around the group, respectively. The two-halo model results in a drastically reduced rms of 0&farcs;06 and a lower BIC of &minus;4. However, we caution that such a low rms is unrealistic in comparison to other well-constrained models in the literature, and may suggest overfitting. It is possible that model C is too flexible, and the lack of constraints west of the group allows it to compensate for the fixed position of DM1 with DM2. We note that its mass distribution is drastically different from the three other models as shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf5\">5</xref> especially in the regions that lack lensing constraints. We conclude that we currently do not have enough information to properly constrain the position of DM2.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf5\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 5.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc5\">\n<p>Projected mass density contours from models A (green), B (cyan), C (magenta), and D (yellow). The total projected mass density shows two components, regardless of modeling choices, with one clump centered near the BCG and one near the nearby group of cluster-member galaxies. Contours are plotted at 0.5, 1, and 2&nbsp;&times;&nbsp;10<sup>9</sup><inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn89.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> kpc<sup>&minus;2</sup></p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf5_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf5.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf5_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf5_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf5_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf5_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<p>We compare models B and D&mdash;both with free &ldquo;main&rdquo; DM halo, but with and without a secondary halo around the group. The mass distributions of the two models are similar, as shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf5\">5</xref>. Model D adds a second DM halo near the group; however, it adds only a little mass to the model&mdash;as can be inferred by its low normalization parameter <italic>&sgr;</italic><sub>0</sub> (Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>). The rms of model B (0&farcs;1) is similar to that of model D (0&farcs;07) even if both remain low in comparison with a well constrainted cluster in the literature. However, the BIC of model B (&minus;16) is significantly better than that for model D (4). This implies that the modeling flexibility offered by the addition of the secondary halo is not required in order to improve the overall goodness of the model.</p>\n<p>Models C and D have similar rms values. Model D has a slightly higher BIC, indicating that there is only little statistical difference between models C and D. Moreover, as can be seen in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>, a fixed versus free position of DM1 results in significantly different positions for DM2, due to the location of the lensing constraints between these two halos. As noted above, with the current lensing evidence, the position of DM2 is severely underconstrained. Further lensing observables west of the group are needed in order to constrain the position of DM2, which will make models using the same assumptions as C and D more reliable.</p>\n<p>In conclusion, given the available constraints, the BIC criterion identifies model B as the one that compromises best between the goodness of the fit and number of constraints and free parameters. Nevertheless, models with two cluster-scale DM halos are not ruled out.</p>\n<p>While our statistical assessment suggests that there could be more than one unique &ldquo;best&rdquo; model that satisfies the lensing constraints, our main conclusions are not significantly affected by the choice of model: The image configurations, regardless of the modeling choices, require that there be two main mass clumps. None of the modeling results differ on that. We discuss this further in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs6\">6</xref>.</p>\n</sec>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs6\">\n<label>6.</label>\n<title>Discussion</title>\n<p>Optical imaging and spectroscopy of SPT-0356 indicate that it has a two-component distribution of cluster-member galaxies, with two main stellar components separated by 21&Prime; (&sim;170 kpc). Our strong lensing analysis finds that the distribution of DM is consistent with that of the galaxies. In this section, we compare the stellar and DM distributions and discuss some of their unusual properties.</p>\n<p>The GMOS spectra of the BCG and two cluster-member galaxies from a nearby group are shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf6\">6</xref> (retrieved from Bayliss et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>), in red, blue, and green lines, respectively. The velocity offset between the BCG and these other galaxies is &lt;300 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>. The spectrum of the BCG shows [O <sc>ii</sc>] in emission, which is indicative of star formation; the other two galaxies show little to no [O <sc>ii</sc>] emission. Observing star formation in a BCG is not unusual, and overall, the spectroscopic data are consistent with these galaxies arising from a similar population of galaxies at the same redshift. The spectrum of this Galaxy does have a velocity offset between the absorption and emission features (&sim;550 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>). This offset could trace an in-falling filament of cooling gas in the cluster core. Velocity difference between galaxies are reported here using the measurement of the absorption features.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf6\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 6.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc6\">\n<p>GMOS spectra of the BCG in red and two other cluster members, part of the group discussed in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs6\">6</xref>, in blue and green. The two galaxies are marked with green squares located in the group of galaxies in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref>. The vertical yellow dashed line marks identified spectral features at the redshifts of the BCG.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf6_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf6.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf6_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf6_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf6_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf6_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<p>All four strong lensing models are consistent with a two-components mass distribution, with one component centered near the BCG and one near the group. Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf5\">5</xref> plots the mass contours derived from models A (green contours), B (cyan contours), C (magenta contours), and D (yellow contours), showing that regardless of modeling choices a secondary mass distribution is needed in order to reproduce the lensing constraints.</p>\n<p>We measure the mass of each of the two main structures, by summing the projected mass density within apertures of 80 kpc radius centered on the BCG and on the group. We choose 80 kpc as it separates on the sky the two structures and allows mass estimates of the two components.</p>\n<p>We report those values in table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt5\">5</xref>, as well as their ratios, for each of the tested models. We find that regardless of the model used, we always find a similar total projected mass ratio between the two structures.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt5\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Table 5</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886btc5\">\n<p>The Projected Masses for Our Four Different Models Enclosed within a Radius of 80 kpc Centered on Two Locations</p>\n</caption>\n<table>\n<colgroup>\n<col
