image</p>\n</caption>\n</graphic>\n<table-wrap-foot>\n<p><bold>Note.</bold> System refers to the name of the group of images coming from the same source Galaxy. ID refers to the name of the image. R.A. and Decl. are the R.A. and decl. position (J2000) of the image. Spec-<italic>z</italic> is the measured spectroscopic redshifts. dist, often called individual rms, refers to the distance in the image plane between the image an the projected geometrical center of the source. For each system the source position is determined by the geometric mean of source plane positions of individual images.</p>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n<p>In addition to the secure, spectroscopically confirmed multiply imaged galaxies, we identify three candidate multiply imaged systems. Since the strong lensing model is used to help identify these candidates, we do not use those systems as constraints. Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt3\">3</xref> indicates the position of the identified multiple image candidate systems.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt3\" image</p>\n</caption>\n</graphic>\n<table-wrap-foot>\n<p><bold>Note.</bold> System refers to the name of the group of images coming from the same source Galaxy. ID refers to the name of the image. R.A. and Decl. are the R.A. and decl. position (J2000) of the image.</p>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5-3\">\n<label>5.3.</label>\n<title>DM Halos</title>\n<p>We compute four models with one or two DM halos and varying free parameters, to investigate the spatial distribution of DM in the cluster core with respect to the stellar component. These models are summarized in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>, and described below.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt4\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Table 4</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886btc4\">\n<p>Candidate Lens Models and Best-fit Parameters</p>\n</caption>\n<table>\n<colgroup>\n<col align=\"left\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n</colgroup>\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">Model Name</th>\n<th align=\"center\">Component</th>\n<th align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\rm{\\Delta brackets are fixed parameters &nbsp; We report statistical quantities such as the Bayesian Information criterion (BIC), the corrected Akaike information criterion (AICc), the likelihood log(<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${ \\mathcal L }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn77.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>) the number of free parameter <italic>k</italic>, and the sample size <italic>n</italic>.</p>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bt4fna\">\n<label><sup>a</sup></label>\n<p>\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">&Delta;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mi>&agr;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn78.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> and <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\delta $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">&Delta;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mi>&delta;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn79.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (<italic>&agr;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;59.0896383, <italic>&delta;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;&minus;53.6310962).</p>\n</fn>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bt4fnb\">\n<label><sup>b</sup></label>\n<p>Ellipticity (<italic>&epsiv;</italic>) is defined to be <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $({a}^{2}-{b}^{2})/({a}^{2}+{b}^{2})$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>a</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>b</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"true\">&sol;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>a</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>b</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn80.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, where <italic>a</italic> and <italic>b</italic> are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.</p>\n</fn>\n<fn id=\"apjab886bt4fnc\">\n<label><sup>c</sup></label>\n<p>\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\sigma }_{0}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&sgr;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn81.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${r}_{\\mathrm{cut}}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>r</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>cut</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn82.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, and <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${r}_{\\mathrm{core}}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>r</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>core</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn83.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> are, respectively, the central velocity dispersion, the cut radius, and the core radius as defined for the dPIE potential used in our modelization. For <italic>L</italic><sup>&ast;</sup> galaxy this value represents the parameter of the galaxy that we optimized for our mass-to-light ratio. We refer the reader to Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-1\">5.1</xref> for a summary, and Limousin et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib29\">2007</xref>) and El&iacute;asd&oacute;ttir et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib18\">2007</xref>) for a more detailed description of the potential. The likelihood is computed as log(<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${ \\mathcal L }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn84.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> &equals; <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $-0.5{\\chi }^{2}.$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.5</mml:mn>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&chi;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mi>.</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn85.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> and the uncertainty used in the <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\chi }^{2}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&chi;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn86.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> computation is computed as <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $\\sigma =\\mathrm{rms}* \\sqrt{(N-k-1)/N}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>&sgr;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>rms</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&ast;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msqrt>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>N</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>k</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"true\">&sol;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>N</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msqrt>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn87.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> where the correcting factor unbiased the rms distribution. We used a unique value of <italic>&sgr;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;0.19 computed using model B. Due to the homogeneity of our individual positional uncertainties (Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt2\">2</xref>, a small variation of the <italic>&sgr;</italic> will not affect our results).</p>\n</fn>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n<p>The spatial distribution of cluster-member galaxies appears to be separate in two components, with a concentration of cluster-member galaxies grouped &sim;150 kpc west of the BCG. The formation of the arcs between the BCG and this concentration of galaxies indicates that the underlying DM mass distribution of the cluster may also show a two-component structure. Similar lensing configurations are seen in several lower-redshift clusters, whose lens models are dominated by two cluster-scale DM halos (e.g., Sharon et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib44\">2020</xref>). To test the hypothesis that this cluster is also dominated by two halos, we compute two sets of lens models: The first set of models, labeled A and B, have one cluster-scale DM halo (DM1 in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>). A second set of models, labeled C and D, have two cluster-scale DM halos (DM1 and DM2 in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>). In models A and C, the center of DM1 is not fixed, adding two free parameters to these models. Contribution of cluster-member galaxies is included in all models in the same way, as explained in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs5-1\">5.1</xref>. DM1 is assumed to be located at or near the position of the BCG, for two reasons. First, the BCG presents a regular luminosity profile which suggests that it is not disturbed and therefore this Galaxy would be at the cluster center. Second, we lack the ability to properly constrain the Eastern extent of the cluster since we do not identify secure lensing constraints in this region at the depth of the existing data. The position of DM2 is free with a loose prior that positions it around the group of galaxies on the western part of the cluster. We chose that location as it is more likely that the DM clump is located close to a luminous counterpart (Broadhurst et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib8\">2000</xref>, <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib7\">2005</xref>).</p>\n<p>The second hypothesis we investigate is whether the BCG and its associated DM halo sit at the center of the cluster-scale DM halo. To test this scenario, we fix the position of DM1 to the position of the BCG in models B and D.</p>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs5-4\">\n<label>5.4.</label>\n<title>Lens Modeling Results</title>\n<p>Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref> lists the best-fit values of the lens model parameters for each one of the four test models. To evaluate the lens models, we employ two statistical criteria, as described below. One criterion is named rms and represents the average difference between the observed position of a multiple image and the predicted position from the geometrical center of the best-fit model in the image plane given in arcseconds. Thus we seek to reduce the rms as much as possible. The models with one cluster-scale DM clump show an rms of 0&farcs;3 and 0&farcs;1 for the fixed and free DM halo respectively. The models with two cluster-scale DM clumps result in better rms of 0&farcs;06 and 0&farcs;07 for the fixed and free DM halo, respectively.</p>\n<p>The rms criterion suggests that the models with two cluster-scale DM halos are significantly better; however, this criterion does not account for the increased flexibility due to the additional free parameters. To account for that, we further evaluate the models using a second criterion, the Bayesian information criterion (BIC), which was presented in previous works (see Section 5.1 in Mahler et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib30\">2018</xref>; Lagattuta et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib28\">2017</xref>; Acebron et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib1\">2017</xref>). The BIC enables a quantitative comparison between similar models; it is a statistical measurement based on the model likelihood <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${ \\mathcal L }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn88.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>, penalized by the number of free parameters <italic>k</italic> and the sample size <italic>n</italic> (i.e., 2&times; the number of multiple images):<disp-formula id=\"apjab886beqn1\">\n<label>1</label>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA \\begin{eqnarray}\\mathrm{BIC}=-2\\times \\mathrm{log}({ \\mathcal L })+k\\times \\mathrm{log}(n).\\end{eqnarray}?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>BIC</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>log</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"italic\">&#x0E238;</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>k</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>log</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>n</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mi>.</mml:mi>\n</mml:math> -->\n<graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886beqn1.gif\"/>\n</disp-formula>We seek to maximize the likelihood (or reduce the first term of Equation (<xref ref-type=\"disp-formula\" rid=\"apjab886beqn1\">1</xref>)). However, arbitrarily increasing the number of free parameters would overfit the data. The second term provides means of balancing the overfitting. It represents a combination of the number of constraints and the number of free parameters and increases the global value of the BIC. We seek the lowest BIC possible. Using the BIC will help us estimate the improvement of the likelihood in comparison with the freedom allowed by the new parameters such as the secondary halo or freeing the position of DM1.</p>\n<p>The number of constraints is identical among all models and is computed as follows:<disp-formula id=\"apjab886beqn2\">\n<label>2</label>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA \\begin{eqnarray}N=({n}_{\\mathrm{im}}\\times 2-{n}_{\\mathrm{src}}\\times 2),\\end{eqnarray}?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>N</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">(</mml:mo>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>n</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>im</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>n</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>src</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo stretchy=\"false\">)</mml:mo>\n<mml:mo>,</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886beqn2.gif\"/>\n</disp-formula>where <italic>n</italic><sub>im</sub> refers to the number of images and <italic>n</italic><sub>src</sub> the number of sources. It is recommended to only compare similar models because otherwise the likelihood will not be a similar description of the model performance.</p>\n<p>We discuss here the performance of the four models. To avoid possible confusion we will refer to the model letter as listed in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>.</p>\n<p>Model A, with one cluster halo at a fixed position, has an rms of 0&farcs;3 and a BIC of 20. Freeing the halo center as was done in model B reduces the rms to 0&farcs;1 and the BIC to &minus;16. This is a considerable improvement, indicating that according to both the rms and the BIC criteria model B, with a free halo, is a better fit to the lensing constraints than model A.</p>\n<p>We compare models A and C&mdash;the two models with fixed &ldquo;main&rdquo; DM halo, but with and without a secondary halo around the group, respectively. The two-halo model results in a drastically reduced rms of 0&farcs;06 and a lower BIC of &minus;4. However, we caution that such a low rms is unrealistic in comparison to other well-constrained models in the literature, and may suggest overfitting. It is possible that model C is too flexible, and the lack of constraints west of the group allows it to compensate for the fixed position of DM1 with DM2. We note that its mass distribution is drastically different from the three other models as shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf5\">5</xref> especially in the regions that lack lensing constraints. We conclude that we currently do not have enough information to properly constrain the position of DM2.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf5\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 5.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc5\">\n<p>Projected mass density contours from models A (green), B (cyan), C (magenta), and D (yellow). The total projected mass density shows two components, regardless of modeling choices, with one clump centered near the BCG and one near the nearby group of cluster-member galaxies. Contours are plotted at 0.5, 1, and 2&nbsp;&times;&nbsp;10<sup>9</sup><inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn89.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> kpc<sup>&minus;2</sup></p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf5_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf5.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf5_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf5_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf5_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf5_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<p>We compare models B and D&mdash;both with free &ldquo;main&rdquo; DM halo, but with and without a secondary halo around the group. The mass distributions of the two models are similar, as shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf5\">5</xref>. Model D adds a second DM halo near the group; however, it adds only a little mass to the model&mdash;as can be inferred by its low normalization parameter <italic>&sgr;</italic><sub>0</sub> (Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>). The rms of model B (0&farcs;1) is similar to that of model D (0&farcs;07) even if both remain low in comparison with a well constrainted cluster in the literature. However, the BIC of model B (&minus;16) is significantly better than that for model D (4). This implies that the modeling flexibility offered by the addition of the secondary halo is not required in order to improve the overall goodness of the model.</p>\n<p>Models C and D have similar rms values. Model D has a slightly higher BIC, indicating that there is only little statistical difference between models C and D. Moreover, as can be seen in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt4\">4</xref>, a fixed versus free position of DM1 results in significantly different positions for DM2, due to the location of the lensing constraints between these two halos. As noted above, with the current lensing evidence, the position of DM2 is severely underconstrained. Further lensing observables west of the group are needed in order to constrain the position of DM2, which will make models using the same assumptions as C and D more reliable.</p>\n<p>In conclusion, given the available constraints, the BIC criterion identifies model B as the one that compromises best between the goodness of the fit and number of constraints and free parameters. Nevertheless, models with two cluster-scale DM halos are not ruled out.</p>\n<p>While our statistical assessment suggests that there could be more than one unique &ldquo;best&rdquo; model that satisfies the lensing constraints, our main conclusions are not significantly affected by the choice of model: The image configurations, regardless of the modeling choices, require that there be two main mass clumps. None of the modeling results differ on that. We discuss this further in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs6\">6</xref>.</p>\n</sec>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs6\">\n<label>6.</label>\n<title>Discussion</title>\n<p>Optical imaging and spectroscopy of SPT-0356 indicate that it has a two-component distribution of cluster-member galaxies, with two main stellar components separated by 21&Prime; (&sim;170 kpc). Our strong lensing analysis finds that the distribution of DM is consistent with that of the galaxies. In this section, we compare the stellar and DM distributions and discuss some of their unusual properties.</p>\n<p>The GMOS spectra of the BCG and two cluster-member galaxies from a nearby group are shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf6\">6</xref> (retrieved from Bayliss et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib2\">2016</xref>), in red, blue, and green lines, respectively. The velocity offset between the BCG and these other galaxies is &lt;300 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>. The spectrum of the BCG shows [O <sc>ii</sc>] in emission, which is indicative of star formation; the other two galaxies show little to no [O <sc>ii</sc>] emission. Observing star formation in a BCG is not unusual, and overall, the spectroscopic data are consistent with these galaxies arising from a similar population of galaxies at the same redshift. The spectrum of this Galaxy does have a velocity offset between the absorption and emission features (&sim;550 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>). This offset could trace an in-falling filament of cooling gas in the cluster core. Velocity difference between galaxies are reported here using the measurement of the absorption features.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf6\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 6.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc6\">\n<p>GMOS spectra of the BCG in red and two other cluster members, part of the group discussed in Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs6\">6</xref>, in blue and green. The two galaxies are marked with green squares located in the group of galaxies in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref>. The vertical yellow dashed line marks identified spectral features at the redshifts of the BCG.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf6_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf6.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf6_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf6_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf6_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf6_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<p>All four strong lensing models are consistent with a two-components mass distribution, with one component centered near the BCG and one near the group. Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf5\">5</xref> plots the mass contours derived from models A (green contours), B (cyan contours), C (magenta contours), and D (yellow contours), showing that regardless of modeling choices a secondary mass distribution is needed in order to reproduce the lensing constraints.</p>\n<p>We measure the mass of each of the two main structures, by summing the projected mass density within apertures of 80 kpc radius centered on the BCG and on the group. We choose 80 kpc as it separates on the sky the two structures and allows mass estimates of the two components.</p>\n<p>We report those values in table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt5\">5</xref>, as well as their ratios, for each of the tested models. We find that regardless of the model used, we always find a similar total projected mass ratio between the two structures.</p>\n<table-wrap id=\"apjab886bt5\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Table 5</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886btc5\">\n<p>The Projected Masses for Our Four Different Models Enclosed within a Radius of 80 kpc Centered on Two Locations</p>\n</caption>\n<table>\n<colgroup>\n<col align=\"left\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n<col align=\"center\"/>\n</colgroup>\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th align=\"left\">Model</th>\n<th align=\"center\"><italic>M</italic><sub>BCG</sub></th>\n<th align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\mathrm{group}}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>group</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn90.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>\n</th>\n<th align=\"center\">Ratio</th>\n<th align=\"center\"><italic>f</italic><sub>CM</sub></th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">A&mdash;1 halo, DM1 fixed</td>\n<td align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${18.9}_{-0.5}^{+0.0}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>18.9</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.5</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> align=\"center\">0.27</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">C&mdash;2 halos, DM1 fixed</td>\n<td align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${15.4}_{-0.0}^{+1.0}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>15.4</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> ${10.9}_{-0.0}^{+5.5}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10.9</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>5.5</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> align=\"center\">0.54</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">D&mdash;2 halos, DM1 free</td>\n<td align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${16.2}_{-1.1}^{+0.0}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>16.2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.1</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn97.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>\n</td>\n<td align=\"center\">\n<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${10.2}_{-0.0}^{+4.8}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10.2</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.0</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>4.8</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn98.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>\n</td>\n<td align=\"center\">1.58</td>\n<td align=\"center\">0.28</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<graphic xlink:href=\"apjab886bt5_tb.gif\"/>\n<graphic xlink:href=\"apjab886bt5_lr.gif\">\n<caption>\n<p>Typeset image</p>\n</caption>\n</graphic>\n<table-wrap-foot>\n<p><bold>Note.</bold> <italic>M</italic><sub>BCG</sub> refers to the mass measured in a circle center on the BCG. <italic>M</italic><sub>group</sub> refers to the mass measured in a circle center on the group. Ratio refers to the ratio of the two previous columns. <italic>f</italic><sub>CM</sub> refers to the fraction of the total mass contained in cluster members, within a 800 kpc circle. All masses indicated in this table are in units of 10<sup>12</sup><inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn99.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>.</p>\n</table-wrap-foot>\n</table-wrap>\n<p>The small radial velocity offset between the BCG and two measured galaxies in the group (only 300 km s<sup>&minus;1</sup>) strongly suggests that most of the motion is transverse; the separation between the two mass clumps is small, 21&Prime; (&sim;170 kpc); and their mass ratio is near-equal. Those aspects fulfill most of the criteria laid out by Dawson et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib16\">2012</xref>), see Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs1\">1</xref>, arguing that this cluster could be a dissociative merger candidate like the Bullet Cluster undergoing a major merger event. Absent additional information on the dynamical state of the hot gas prevents us from being conclusive regarding its state. Indeed, the cluster can either be in a premerger state or has gone through a very recent merger. High resolution X-ray data can distinguish between these scenarios. This arrangement, where the BCG is spatially separated from other cluster members is atypical, and supports the conclusion that we are observing a major merger event.</p>\n<p>Examination of the two main mass concentrations reveals that their galaxy content is significantly different. One component is dominated by a BCG, with a half-light radius larger than any other cluster member. The other component is composed of a group of eight cluster members. While it is unlikely that this apparent clustering of eight galaxies within&nbsp;&sim;9&Prime; (&sim;70 kpc) is only due to a projection effect, larger spectroscopic coverage could tackle this issue, as would a more refined red sequence based solely on HST data.</p>\n<p>In Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf7\">7</xref> we present the mass and density profiles for the four different models. The statistical uncertainties of the models are very low (&lt;3&percnt;), and, for clarity, they are not shown in this figure. The error budget is dominated by systematic uncertainties due to various assumptions and modeling choices. Our parametric modeling of the cluster mass distribution allows us to isolate the different mass components that contribute to the total mass: cluster-scale DM clumps, the BCG, and the total contribution from the cluster members. We expect degeneracies between the BCG and the core mass of the DM halo at least in some of the models, because they are both confined to the same location. The result is a large variation in the mass of the BCG between models; however, this component represents only a small fraction of the total mass.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf7\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure 7.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc7\">\n<p>Integrated (upper panel), and differential (lower panel) mass profile of the cluster. The mass profiles are drawn from a circular aperture centered on the BCG. The color coding shows the total mass profiles as well as the different subcomponents. The solid and dashed lines represent the set of models with one dark matter halo and two dark matter halos, respectively. The blue dot marks the estimated SZ mass coming from the 2D projected mass derived from the mass from Bocquet et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib6\">2019</xref>)</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf7_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf7.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf7_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf7_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf7_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf7_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<p>The total contribution from cluster member galaxies appears to be a large fraction of the total mass. As can be seen in Table <xref ref-type=\"table\" rid=\"apjab886bt5\">5</xref>, the different models predict that about 27&percnt;&ndash;54&percnt; of the total mass is contained in the cluster member galaxies and their associated DM halos. This is a result of our fitting procedure that allows a constant mass-to-light ratio to vary in amplitude. In an analysis of a lower-redshift cluster merger, MACS J0417.5&minus;154, Mahler et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib31\">2019</xref>) found a significantly smaller ratio between the Galaxy and cluster contributions of about 1&percnt;. Wu et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib57\">2013</xref>) investigated this ratio using simulated clusters and reported that up to 20&percnt; of the total mass is contained in subhalos that survived the merger with the main halo, although with large scatter, and strong dependence on formation time. In a future analysis of a large sample of clusters, we will investigate whether this is indicative of an evolutionary trend with cosmic time, or an anecdotal representation of a larger cluster-to-cluster variation.</p>\n<p>Several aspects of this analysis would be better constrained with additional data, primarily multiband high-resolution imaging, from HST, and with high resolution X-ray observations. Multiband HST observations, extending to the near-IR, would refine the red-sequence selection of cluster-member galaxies and provide a handle on their stellar mass through spectral energy distribution fitting. These data would also facilitate the detection of new multiple images and the confirmation of image candidates in the east and west parts of the cluster, which are under-constrained with the current data. X-ray observations are necessary for determining the dynamical state of the hot cluster gas. A signature of a shock between the components would indicate a recent major merger (Poole et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib42\">2007</xref>), while X-ray emission from both structures would support a premerger scenario.</p>\n</sec>\n<sec id=\"apjab886bs7\">\n<label>7.</label>\n<title>Summary</title>\n<p>We construct a strong lensing mass model of the Galaxy cluster SPT-CL J0356&minus;5337 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.0359, one of the highest-redshift strong lensing clusters known to date. We present spectroscopic confirmation and redshifts of three multiply imaged lensed galaxies, whose images appear 9&farcs;5&ndash;15&Prime; west of the BCG. The lensed galaxies are spatially resolved, allowing us to use different emission knots in the same system as constraints, which adds leverage on the shape of the mass profile. This provides confidence in our ability to accurately probe the mass distribution, which at the location of the lensing evidence, is constrained to within a few percent. However, the lack of multiply imaged systems at the outskirts of the cluster core limits our understanding of the cluster halo. Nevertheless, SPT-0356 appears to be the best-constrained lensing cluster at this redshift bin to date. Other cluster-scale lenses either have too few lensing constraints, are not spectroscopically confirmed, or their apparent lensing evidence is dominated by single galaxies rather than the cluster potential (see Section <xref ref-type=\"sec\" rid=\"apjab886bs1\">1</xref>).</p>\n<p>We employ statistical criteria to evaluate four possible lens models, which are based on different modeling assumptions. The lens model indicates that SPT-0356 has an Einstein radius of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${\\theta }_{{\\rm{E}}}\\simeq $?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>&theta;</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">E</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&simeq;</mml:mo>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn100.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> 14&Prime; measured based on the tangential critical curve for a source at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;3. At a radius of 500 kpc the enclosed mass is measured to be <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{500\\mathrm{kpc}}=4.0\\pm 0.8\\times {10}^{14}\\,$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>500</mml:mn>\n<mml:mspace width=\"0.25em\"/>\n<mml:mi>kpc</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>4.0</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&PlusMinus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.8</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>14</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:mspace width=\"0.25em\"/>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn101.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn102.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> . We report in our model within a radius of 820 kpc (<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $\\simeq {R}_{500c}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mo>&simeq;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>R</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>500</mml:mn>\n<mml:mi>c</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn103.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> computed using the spherical mass from <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{500c}={3.59}_{-0.66}^{+0.59}\\times {10}^{14}{h}_{70}^{-1}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>500</mml:mn>\n<mml:mi>c</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>3.59</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.66</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.59</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>14</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>h</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>70</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn104.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn105.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> from Bocquet et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib6\">2019</xref>) ) a value of <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $M=4.3\\pm 0.8\\times {10}^{14}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>4.3</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&PlusMinus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>0.8</mml:mn>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>14</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn106.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn107.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> statistically favored model (B) consistent with the SPT estimated cylindrical mass <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{500c}^{2{\\rm{D}}}={7.45}_{-1.46}^{+1.23}\\times {10}^{14}$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>500</mml:mn>\n<mml:mi>c</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>2</mml:mn>\n<mml:mi mathvariant=\"normal\">D</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>7.45</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&minus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.46</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&plus;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.23</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msubsup>\n<mml:mo>&times;</mml:mo>\n<mml:msup>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>10</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mn>14</mml:mn>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msup>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn108.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> <inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA ${M}_{\\odot }$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:msub>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mi>M</mml:mi>\n</mml:mrow>\n<mml:mrow>\n<mml:mo>&CircleDot;</mml:mo>\n</mml:mrow>\n</mml:msub>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn109.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula> at that same radius. We used the formula provided in Hu &amp; Kravtsov (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib24\">2003</xref>) and the mass-concentration relation from Child et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib11\">2018</xref>).</p>\n<p>Regardless of modeling assumptions, we find that the projected mass density of the cluster is best described by a two-component mass distribution, with one mass substructure centered around the BCG, and a second mass substructure centered on the observed position of a small group of eight cluster-member galaxies, grouped within a radius of &sim;9&Prime; (&sim;70 kpc) diameter circle, located &sim;170 kpc west of the BCG. The lensing analysis points to a nearly equal mass between the two substructures of SPT-0356. Nevertheless, the Galaxy distribution is significantly different between those mass components&mdash;one dominated by a single Galaxy, the other hosting a group of eight galaxies.</p>\n<p>The similar masses, the low radial velocity offset between the group and the BCG, and the small impact parameter between the two structures, suggest that this cluster is undergoing a major-merger event. However, to fully characterize this system as a dissociative merger, we would require deep X-ray imaging to probe its intracluster medium and constrain the dynamical state of the cluster gas. If confirmed, SPT-0356 will be an important <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&gt;&nbsp;1 target for next-generation X-ray telescopes.</p>\n<p>We find a high mass ratio between the mass associated with cluster-member galaxies to the cluster-scale DM halos at the core of the cluster compared to low mass clusters, perhaps indicating that the subhalos are yet to lose a significant fraction of their DM to the cluster potential. All evidence in hand suggests that SPT-0356 provides a unique opportunity to probe the population of high-redshift clusters, and to study the evolution of massive clusters.</p>\n</sec> </body>\n<back>\n<ack>\n<p>We thank the referee for very meaningful and significant comments that helped improve the paper. G.M. thanks Benjamin Cl&eacute;ment for very useful conversations and insights that improved the quality of the paper. This work is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, using imaging data from GO program 13412. STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS5-26555. This paper includes data gathered with the 6.5 meter Magellan Telescopes located at Las Campanas Observatory, Chile. Based on observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under a cooperative agreement with the NSF on behalf of the Gemini partnership: the National Science Foundation (United States), the National Research Council (Canada), CONICYT (Chile), the Australian Research Council (Australia), Minist&eacute;rio da Ci&ecirc;ncia, Tecnologia e Inova&ccedil;&atilde;o (Brazil) and Ministerio de Ciencia, Tecnolog&iacute;a e Innovaci&oacute;n Productiva (Argentina). T.S. and J.L.v.d.B. acknowledge support from the German Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology (BMWi) provided through DLR under project 50 OR 1407. Work at Argonne National Lab is supported by UChicago Argonne LLC,Operator of Argonne National Laboratory. Argonne, a U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science Laboratory, is operated under contract No. DE-AC02-06CH11357. This research used resources of the Argonne Leadership Computing Facility, which is a DOE Office of Science User Facility supported under Contract DE-AC02-06CH11357. Work at Argonne National Lab is supported by UChicago Argonne LLC,Operator of Argonne National Laboratory (Argonne). Argonne, a U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science Laboratory, is operated under contract No. DE-AC02-06CH11357.</p>\n<p><italic>Facilities:</italic> <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\"HST\"><italic>HST</italic>(ACS)</named-content>, <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\" SPT\"> SPT</named-content>, <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\" Magellan(LDSS3C\"> Magellan(LDSS3C</named-content>, <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\" IMACS\"> IMACS</named-content>, <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\" PISCO\"> PISCO</named-content>, <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\" FIRE)\"> FIRE)</named-content>, <named-content content-type=\"facility\" xlink:href=\" Gemini.\"> Gemini(GMOS).</named-content>\n</p>\n</ack>\n<app-group id=\"apjab886bapp\">\n<app id=\"apjab886bapp1\">\n<label>Appendix A</label>\n<title>The Jellyfish Galaxy</title>\n<p>We identify a Galaxy at the cluster redshift (<italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.017) that exhibits significant star formation based on its colors, and asymmetric morphology with trails of star formation knots (<italic>&agr;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;3:56:22.310, <italic>&delta;</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;&minus;53:37:52.700; marked with orange circle in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf1\">1</xref>). Galaxies with such properties are often referred to in the literature as &ldquo;jellyfish&rdquo; galaxies (e.g., Suyu &amp; Halkola <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib53\">2010</xref>; Ebeling et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib17\">2014</xref>), and are believed to be undergoing stripping as they fall into the intracluster medium, inducing star formation. The projected distance between this galaxy and the BCG is &sim;60&nbsp;kpc. The redshift corresponds to a velocity offset of 2359 km s<sup>&minus;1 </sup>between the &ldquo;jellyfish&rdquo; Galaxy and the BCG, or 2783 km s<sup>&minus;1 </sup>relative to the median cluster redshift <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.0359. As the ratio between the velocity and the velocity dispersion is <italic>v</italic>/<italic>&sgr;</italic><sub><italic>v</italic></sub>&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;2, and given its small projected distance from the cluster core, it is likely that this galaxy is gravitationally bound to the cluster (Bayliss et al. <xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib3\">2017</xref>).</p>\n<p>The apparent stripped gas of the jellyfish suggests that the trajectory on the plane of sky may be from a northwest position. The green dashed arrow shown in Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf8\">A1</xref> represents a best guess of the jellyfish trajectory, following McPartland et al. (<xref ref-type=\"bibr\" rid=\"apjab886bbib37\">2016</xref>). The bluer redshift of the jellyfish (<italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp;1.017) compared to the cluster (<inline-formula>\n<tex-math>\n<?CDATA $z=1.0359$?>\n</tex-math>\n<!-- <mml:math>\n<mml:mi>z</mml:mi>\n<mml:mo>&equals;</mml:mo>\n<mml:mn>1.0359</mml:mn>\n</mml:math> -->\n<inline-graphic xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bieqn110.gif\"/>\n</inline-formula>) indicates that the jellyfish Galaxy is moving toward us in comparison to the rest of the cluster.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf8\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure A1.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc8\">\n<p>Left: HST image of the observed jellyfish Galaxy in the Galaxy cluster, the dashed arrow line represents a projection of the estimated trajectory of the jellyfish Galaxy. Right: spectral features identified in the FIRE spectra within the slit targeting the jellyfish Galaxy.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf8_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf8.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf8_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf8_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf8_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf8_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n</app>\n<app id=\"apjab886bapp2\">\n<label>Appendix B</label>\n<title>FIRE Spectra</title>\n<p>In this appendix we present sections of the spectra for the lensed galaxy image 1.1 (Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf9\">B1</xref>); images 2.1 and 2.3 (Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf10\">B2</xref>); and images 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 (Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf11\">B3</xref>). These figures highlight the spectral features that were used to measure the spectroscopic redshifts of these galaxies.</p>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf9\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure B1.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc9\">\n<p>Spectral features identified in the FIRE spectra of image&nbsp;1.1 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp; 2.363.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf9_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf9.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf9_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf9_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf9_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf9_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf10\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure B2.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc10\">\n<p>Spectral features identified in the FIRE spectra for two images of system&nbsp;2 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp; 2.364. Top: image&nbsp;2.1; bottom: image&nbsp;2.3.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf10_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf10.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf10_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf10_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf10_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf10_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n<fig id=\"apjab886bf11\" position=\"float\">\n<label>Figure B3.</label>\n<caption id=\"apjab886bfc11\">\n<p>Spectral features identified in the FIRE spectra for three images of system&nbsp;3 at <italic>z</italic>&nbsp;&equals;&nbsp; 3.048. Top: image&nbsp;3.1; middle: image&nbsp;3.2; bottom: image&nbsp;3.3.</p>\n</caption>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf11_eps\" content-type=\"print\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf11.eps\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf11_lr\" content-type=\"low\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf11_lr.jpg\"/>\n<graphic id=\"apjab886bf11_hr\" content-type=\"high\" xlink:href=\"apjab886bf11_hr.jpg\"/>\n</fig>\n</app>\n</app-group>\n<ref-list content-type=\"alphabetical\">\n<title>References</title>\n<ref id=\"apjab886bbib1\">\n<element-citation publication-type=\"journal\">\n<person-group person-group-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Acebron</surname>\n<given-names>A.</given-names>\n</name>\n<name>\n<surname>Jullo</surname>\n<given-names>E.</given-names>\n</name>\n<name>\n<surname>Limousin</surname>\n<given-names>M.</given-names>\n</name>\n<etal/>\n</person-group>\n<year>2017</year>\n<source>MNRAS</source>\n<volume>470</volume>\n<fpage>1809</fpage>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"bibcode\">2017MNRAS.470.1809A</ext-link>\n<pub-id pub-id-type=\"doi\">10.1093/mnras/stx1330</pub-id>\n</element-citation>\n</ref>\n<ref id=\"apjab886bbib2\">\n<element-citation publication-type=\"journal\">\n<person-group person-group-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Bayliss</surname>\n<given-names>M. S.</given-names>\n</name>\n<name>\n<surname>Mao</surname>\n<given-names>Y.-Y.</given-names>\n</name>\n</person-group>\n<year>2013</year>\n<source>ApJ</source>\n<volume>767</volume>\n<fpage>23</fpage>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"bibcode\">2013ApJ...767...23W</ext-link>\n<pub-id pub-id-type=\"doi\">10.1088/0004-637X/767/1/23</pub-id>\n</element-citation>\n</ref>\n<ref id=\"apjab886bbib58\">\n<element-citation publication-type=\"journal\">\n<person-group person-group-type=\"author\">\n<name>\n<surname>Zitrin</surname>\n<given-names>A.</given-names>\n</name>\n<name>\n<surname>Fabris</surname>\n<given-names>A.</given-names>\n</name>\n<name>\n<surname>Merten</surname>\n<given-names>J.</given-names>\n</name>\n<etal/>\n</person-group>\n<year>2015</year>\n<source>ApJ</source>\n<volume>801</volume>\n<fpage>44</fpage>\n<ext-link ext-link-type=\"bibcode\">2015ApJ...801...44Z</ext-link>\n<pub-id pub-id-type=\"doi\">10.1088/0004-637X/801/1/44</pub-id>\n</element-citation>\n</ref>\n</ref-list>\n</back>\n</article>\n", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": ">In Figure <xref ref-type=\"fig\" rid=\"apjab886bf7\">7</xref> we present the mass and density profiles for the four different models. The statistical uncertainties of the models are very low (&lt;3&percnt;), and, for clarity, they are not shown in this figure. The error budget is dominated by systematic uncertainties due to various assumptions and modeling choices. Our parametric modeling of the cluster mass distribution allows us to isolate the different mass components that contribute to the total mass: cluster-scale DM clumps, the BCG, and the total contribution from the cluster members. We expect degeneracies between the BCG and the core mass of the DM halo at least in some of the models, because they are both confined to the same location. The result is a large variation in the mass of the BCG between models; however, this component represents only a small fraction of the total mass."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": Spec-z is the measured spectroscopic redshifts. dist, often called individual rms, refers to the distance in the image plane between the image an the projected geometrical center of the source. Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters   We report statistical quantities such as the Bayesian Information criterion (BIC), the corrected Akaike information criterion (AICc), the likelihood log(${ \\mathcal L }$) the number of free parameter k, and the sample size n.\n^a ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha $ and ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\delta $ are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (alpha = 59.0896383, delta = -53.6310962).\n^b Ellipticity (epsiv) is defined to be $({a}^{2}-{b}^{2})/({a}^{2}+{b}^{2})$, where a and b are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.\n^c ${\\sigma }_{0}$, ${r}_{\\mathrm{cut}}$, and ${r}_{\\mathrm{core}}$ are, respectively, the central velocity dispersion, the cut radius, and the core radius as defined for the dPIE potential used in our modelization. For L^* galaxy this value represents the parameter of the galaxy that we optimized for our mass-to-light ratio. We refer the reader to Section 5.1 for a summary, and Limousin et al. (2007) and Eliasdottir et al. (2007) for a more detailed description of the potential. The likelihood is computed as log(${ \\mathcal L }$ = $-0.5{\\chi }^{2}.$ and the uncertainty used in the ${\\chi }^{2}$ computation is computed as $\\sigma =\\mathrm{rms}* \\sqrt{(N-k-1)/N}$ where the correcting factor unbiased the rms distribution. We used a unique value of sigma = 0.19 computed using model B. Due to the homogeneity of our individual positional uncertainties (Table 2, a small variation of the sigma will not affect our results).\n", "Status": "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": "Table 4 \nCandidate Lens Models and Best-fit Parameters", "Info after table 1": "Notes. Quantities in brackets are fixed parameters   We report statistical quantities such as the Bayesian Information criterion (BIC), the corrected Akaike information criterion (AICc), the likelihood log(${ \\mathcal L }$) the number of free parameter k, and the sample size n.\n^a ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\alpha $ and ${\\rm{\\Delta }}\\delta $ are measured relative to the reference coordinate point: (alpha = 59.0896383, delta = -53.6310962).\n^b Ellipticity (epsiv) is defined to be $({a}^{2}-{b}^{2})/({a}^{2}+{b}^{2})$, where a and b are the semimajor and semiminor axes of the ellipse.\n^c ${\\sigma }_{0}$, ${r}_{\\mathrm{cut}}$, and ${r}_{\\mathrm{core}}$ are, respectively, the central velocity dispersion, the cut radius, and the core radius as defined for the dPIE potential used in our modelization. For L^* galaxy this value represents the parameter of the galaxy that we optimized for our mass-to-light ratio. We refer the reader to Section 5.1 for a summary, and Limousin et al. (2007) and Eliasdottir et al. (2007) for a more detailed description of the potential. The likelihood is computed as log(${ \\mathcal L }$ = $-0.5{\\chi }^{2}.$ and the uncertainty used in the ${\\chi }^{2}$ computation is computed as $\\sigma =\\mathrm{rms}* \\sqrt{(N-k-1)/N}$ where the correcting factor unbiased the rms distribution. We used a unique value of sigma = 0.19 computed using model B. Due to the homogeneity of our individual positional uncertainties (Table 2, a small variation of the sigma will not affect our results).\n"}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skipping since duplicate": ""}}}}}, "Table set 5": {"Link": "/uufs/chpc.utah.edu/common/home/astro/brownstein/talbot/research/silo/data/tables_backup/hand_from_dropbox/ApJ/894/150/apjab886bt5_ascii.txt", "Response": "Table 5 \nThe Projected Masses for Our Four Different Models Enclosed within a Radius of 80 kpc Centered on Two Locations\n\n\nModel\tM_BCG\t${M}_{\\mathrm{group}}$\tRatio\tf_CM\t\nA - 1 halo, DM1 fixed\t${18.9}_{-0.5}^{+0.0}$\t${15.1}_{-0.0}^{+3.3}$\t1.25\t0.46\t\nB - 1 halo, DM1 free\t${17.0}_{-0.3}^{+0.0}$\t${11.0}_{-0.0}^{+5.7}$\t1.55\t0.27\t\nC - 2 halos, DM1 fixed\t${15.4}_{-0.0}^{+1.0}$\t${10.9}_{-0.0}^{+5.5}$\t1.41\t0.54\t\nD - 2 halos, DM1 free\t${16.2}_{-1.1}^{+0.0}$\t${10.2}_{-0.0}^{+4.8}$\t1.58\t0.28\t\nNote.
